[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The PeaZip (v2.7.1) defines requirements for a cross-platform archive manager supporting ZIP, TAR, and 7Z.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: PeaZip offers a GUI for archiving, compressing, and extracting files across platforms.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: PeaZip supports GUI and command-line operations.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: PeaZip runs on x86-compatible systems, optimized for multi-core environments.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: PeaZip supports ZIP, TAR, and 7Z via zlib and LZMA libraries.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.5 Communications Interfa: PeaZip uses secure protocols like HTTPS and SFTP.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: PeaZip maintains stability with failover mechanisms.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: PeaZip supports centralized and portable setups, including USB.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: PeaZip connects with vendor APIs for extended format compatibility.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 MISSING-TAG2: PeaZip integrates with file systems, APIs, and databases.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: PeaZip provides archiving, secure deletion, and two-factor authentication.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: PeaZip serves general users, IT professionals, and security-conscious users.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.6 Limitations: PeaZip performance depends on user-selected algorithms and hardware.
[SUBSEC] 1.8 Definitions: Checksum: A value for verifying data integrity.
Hash: A unique identifier derived from data.
[SUBSEC] 1.9 Acronyms and Abbreviations: MIPS: Millions of Instructions per Second
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 MISSING-TAG1: PeaZip requires a compatible OS, CPU, and necessary software libraries.

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall integrate with file systems and APIs.
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall support drag-and-drop functionality.

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-001: The system shall allow users to create, update, extract archives and securely delete files.
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall support two-factor authentication for secure archiving (REQ-FUNC-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The system shall offer an accessible, user-friendly interface.
[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-002: The system shall include tutorials and help files (REQ-USAB-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall extract standard archives in 5 seconds.
[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-002: The system shall handle archive files up to 4GB without performance degradation (REQ-PERF-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall store configurations and preferences locally.
[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-002: The system shall maintain data integrity during concurrent operations (REQ-DB-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall comply with open-source licensing standards.
[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-002: The system shall be portable across OS platforms.

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-001: The system shall log critical actions and notify job status changes.

[SUBSEC] 2.7 MISSING-TAG3.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall adhere to POSIX standards for compatibility.

[SEC] 3. Verification: Unit, integration, and performance tests validate functionality.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: User manuals, help files, and tutorials provide guidance.
[SEC] 5. References: PeaZip SourceForge, Wiki, and POSIX documentation.
